title: Logical Fallacies
summary: Spot, name, and neutralize common reasoning errors across five categories—without weaponizing labels.

lessons.title: Why Fallacies Matter (Charity First)
key_ideas: Purpose: Fallacies are tools to improve clarity and fairness, not to 'win' arguments.
Principle of Charity (steel-manning): First restate the strongest sensible version of the other view.
Don’t weaponize labels: Naming a fallacy is not a substitute for showing why the reasoning fails.
Outcome: Better conversations, fewer misfires, and clearer decisions.
examples: Charitable restatement: “You’re saying we should slow rollouts to reduce risk, even if it delays features.” — Explanation: Strongest fair version of their claim.
Uncharitable 'gotcha': “That’s a slippery slope!” — Explanation: Labeling without explaining the missing mechanism does not help reasoning.
Fixing misuse: “It could be a straw man if we oversimplify; let’s quote their exact proposal.” — Explanation: Moves from accusation to accurate summary.

quick_checks.question: Best first move when you suspect a fallacy?
choices: Ask to restate their view charitably.
feedback: Avoiding the issue doesn’t improve reasoning.

quick_checks.question: “That’s ad hominem, so you’re wrong.” What’s missing?
choices: An explanation of why the attack is irrelevant to the claim.
feedback: Correct—show how the personal attack fails to address reasons.

quick_checks.question: Which is most charitable?
choices: “You propose limited phone use to reduce distraction.”

quick_checks.question: Good practice after spotting a fallacy?
choices: Offer a neutral rewrite of the claim.
feedback: Correct—improves clarity and keeps discussion productive.
Sometimes necessary, but not a reasoning step.

quick_checks.question: What shows fair-mindedness?
choices: Acknowledging any valid point in the other side.

quick_checks.question: Best feedback on a suspected straw man?
choices: “Here’s their exact quote; let’s respond to this version instead.”
feedback: Correct—use accurate quotation to correct misrepresentation.

minigame.title: Charity Meter
minigame.prompt: Pick the most charitable restatement of: “Ban phones in class to improve focus.”
options: “They propose limited in-class restrictions to reduce distraction.”
minigame.correct_option: They propose limited in-class restrictions to reduce distraction.
minigame.explanation: This restatement is accurate, neutral, and focuses on the stated goal.

lessons.title: Category 1 — Person & Diversion
key_ideas: Ad Hominem: attacking the person instead of the argument (abusive, circumstantial, tu quoque).
Straw Man: misrepresenting someone’s view to make it easier to attack.
Red Herring: introducing an irrelevant point to distract.
False Dilemma: presenting only two options when more exist.
examples: Ad Hominem: “Don’t listen to her climate data—she’s not even a scientist.” — Explanation: Ignores the data’s merits, targets the speaker.
Straw Man: “You support reform, so you want lawlessness.” — Explanation: Exaggerates a moderate proposal into an extreme.
Red Herring: “Why discuss school funding when the cafeteria pizza is terrible?” — Explanation: Switches to an irrelevant complaint.
False Dilemma: “Either ban phones entirely or accept chaos.” — Explanation: Hides middle options like limited use or norms.

quick_checks.question: “Your policy is wrong because you were fired from your last job.” Identify the fallacy.
“They say we need better safety; next they’ll force us to walk to work!”
feedback: Still on topic but misrep, not distraction.

quick_checks.question: “Why talk about oceans when potholes exist?”
“Either censor harmful posts or society collapses.”
“Your argument is invalid because you’re a hypocrite.”
“If you don’t love X, you must hate it.”

minigame.title: Fallacy Swiper I
minigame.prompt: Classify: “Don’t trust his budget plan—he cheated in college.”
minigame.explanation: Attacks character instead of addressing the plan’s content.

lessons.title: Category 2 — Appeals & Emotion
key_ideas: Appeal to Authority: citing authority as proof when expertise/relevance is weak.
Appeal to Ignorance: claiming something is true because it hasn’t been proven false (or vice versa).
Bandwagon: arguing something is true/good because it’s popular.
Appeal to Emotion: using fear/pity/anger as the main reason.
examples: Authority: “A famous actor says this diet works, so it works.” — Explanation: Fame ≠ expertise in nutrition.
Ignorance: “No one proved aliens aren’t here; therefore, they are.” — Explanation: Absence of disproof isn’t proof.
Bandwagon: “Millions use it; it must be the best.” — Explanation: Popularity ≠ evidence of quality.
Emotion: “Think of the children! Therefore pass this unrelated bill.” — Explanation: Fear/concern replaces relevant reasons.

quick_checks.question: “A Nobel physicist recommends this crypto coin, so buy it.”
“No one disproved the claim, so it’s true.”
“Everyone in my feed invests in it—don’t miss out.”
“If you care about safety, you must support this unrelated policy.”
feedback: Correct—fear/concern used in place of reasons.

quick_checks.question: “This post has 1M likes; it’s definitely true.”
“A cardiologist says this history book is wrong; therefore it’s wrong.”

minigame.title: Emotion or Evidence?
minigame.prompt: “This app saved my life—therefore you must approve it.” What’s the fallacy?
minigame.explanation: Personal drama is not evidence of general effectiveness.

lessons.title: Category 3 — Causal Confusions
key_ideas: Post Hoc: assuming A→B because B followed A.
Cum Hoc: assuming A→B because A and B occur together (correlation).
Slippery Slope: claiming small step → inevitable extreme without mechanism.
Correlation ≠ Causation: requires mechanism, timing, controls, or stronger designs.
examples: Post Hoc: “I took vitamin C and my cold ended; vitamin C cured it.” — Explanation: Recovery may happen naturally; sequence ≠ cause.
Cum Hoc: “Screen time and anxiety correlate; screens cause anxiety.” — Explanation: Could be bidirectional or confounded.
Slippery Slope: “Allow this minor change and chaos follows.” — Explanation: Predicts extremes without showing the chain/mechanism.

quick_checks.question: “I wore lucky socks and we won—socks caused the win.”
feedback: Correct—after this, therefore because of this.

quick_checks.question: “Cities with more bike lanes have more cafés; lanes cause cafés.”
“If phones are allowed at lunch, attention will be zero in class.”
Best first step to test correlation vs causation?
“After installing new software, sales rose; software caused rise.”
“Coffee and productivity correlate; coffee causes productivity.”
feedback: Correct—could be reverse cause or third factor.

minigame.title: Causal Detective
minigame.prompt: Claim: “More ice cream → more drownings.” What’s most likely?
options: A confounder like hot weather increases both.
minigame.correct_option: A confounder like hot weather increases both.
minigame.explanation: A third factor can raise both; test with controls.

lessons.title: Category 4 — Evidence & Sampling
key_ideas: Hasty Generalization: generalizing from too small/unrepresentative a sample.
Cherry-Picking: selecting only supportive data, ignoring counter-evidence.
Biased Sample: sample excludes key groups or over-represents others.
Anecdotal Evidence: vivid story used in place of representative data.
examples: Hasty: “Two friends had side effects; the medicine is unsafe.” — Explanation: Sample too small to generalize.
Cherry-Picking: “Start the chart at 2019 to exaggerate the drop.” — Explanation: Selective window misleads.
Biased Sample: “Survey only premium users.” — Explanation: Frame omits critical populations.
Anecdote: “One review said it failed; the product is bad.” — Explanation: A single story ≠ base rates.

quick_checks.question: “We asked three attendees; everyone loved it!”
feedback: One story can feed hasty, but size is key.
Could also be biased, but size stands out.

quick_checks.question: “Graph starts last month; huge spike!”
“Only premium subscribers surveyed; 99% satisfied.”
feedback: Size may be fine; frame is not.

quick_checks.question: “My uncle thrived on the diet; it’s best for everyone.”
feedback: Could overlap, but anecdote is core.
Often related, but here it’s a single case.

quick_checks.question: Best way to improve generalizability?
choices: Increase sample size and represent key groups.
Ask the most enthusiastic users only.

quick_checks.question: “We removed outliers until the result matched expectations.”
feedback: Correct—selective exclusion to fit a story.
Sample frame isn’t the stated issue.

minigame.title: Study Smarts
options: Increase sample size and ensure it represents key groups.
Use only the happiest users—it’s efficient.
minigame.correct_option: Increase sample size and ensure it represents key groups.
minigame.explanation: Representative, adequately large samples strengthen inductive support.

lessons.title: Category 5 — Ambiguity & Framing
key_ideas: Equivocation: using a key term in different senses within the same argument.
Amphiboly: syntactic/grammatical ambiguity leads to confusion.
Loaded Question: presupposes guilt/assumption ('Have you stopped…?').
Persuasive Definition: smuggling values into a definition to bias judgment.
examples: Equivocation: “Feathers are light; light can’t be dark; so feathers can’t be dark.” — Explanation: 'Light' shifts meaning.
Amphiboly: “Students who pass quickly get prizes.” — Explanation: Ambiguous structure: who’s quick at what?
Loaded Question: “Why are you hiding the data?” — Explanation: Presupposes wrongdoing regardless of answer.
Persuasive Definition: “Tax relief.” — Explanation: Defines taxes as a 'disease' to bias judgment.

quick_checks.question: “This plan is ‘unpatriotic’ because it questions authority.”
“Have you stopped manipulating the numbers?”
“Nothing is better than perfect peace. A sandwich is better than nothing. So a sandwich is better than perfect peace.”
“Visiting relatives can be boring.” (used to argue relatives are boring)
feedback: Falls into fallacy if ambiguity is exploited.

quick_checks.question: “Light things can’t be heavy; this room is light; so it can’t be heavy.”
Neutral rewrite for clarity?
choices: “Removes two categories of posts flagged as violent threats.”

minigame.title: Define & Refine
minigame.prompt: Pick the neutral rewrite: “This policy is censorship.”
options: This policy is an attempt to silence dissenters.
This policy removes two categories of posts flagged as violent threats.
minigame.correct_option: This policy removes two categories of posts flagged as violent threats.
minigame.explanation: Defines specific actions without loaded language—clearer for evaluation.

creator_challenge.title: Steel-Man & Diagnose
creator_challenge.instructions: Find a real post or short article. 1) Steel-man the central claim in 3 sentences. 2) Identify any fallacy category present and justify in 2–3 sentences. 3) Provide a neutral rewrite that removes the fallacy.
